I'll create questions that move from surface to depth, and that connect to their work (I know they're working on Islamic psychology scholar personality assessments).Alright, I've read through your paper on Ibn Qayyim. Rather than just summarize it back to you, let me ask you some questions that'll help us both figure out what you're actually grasping here:

**1. The Architecture Question:**
Ibn Qayyim presents this sequence: thought (fikr) → knowledge (ilm) → knowledge structure (haal) → motivation (iradah) → behavior. But he also presents four types of thinking (tafakkur, tadhakur, i'tibar, tadabur). How do these two frameworks relate to each other? Are they describing the same process at different resolutions, or are they parallel systems?

**2. The Tension Question:**
The paper claims Ibn Qayyim says "any pleasure that results in pain is an illegitimate pleasure" and therefore "the only worthy pleasure is in the worship of God." But his first category of pleasure is survival needs - food, shelter, procreation. These definitely can result in pain. Is this a contradiction, or is there something more nuanced going on that the paper isn't capturing?

You're building personality assessments based on medieval Islamic psychological frameworks. Which of Ibn Qayyim's contributions here would actually be *measurable* or *observable* in a way that could inform an assessment? And which are more philosophical/theological constructs that might resist that kind of operationalization?

**4. The Missing Piece Question:**
The paper repeatedly mentions that Ibn Qayyim's works aren't well translated and that Islamic contributions between Greek philosophy and the Renaissance are ignored. But - does this paper actually demonstrate that Ibn Qayyim's ideas influenced modern psychology, or just that they're parallel? What's the difference, and why does it matter?

Start with whichever question pulls at you. I'm curious where your understanding is solid and where it's more like "I read these words but I'm not sure I've really *got* it yet."

Ibn Al Qayyim and Contribution to Psychology: Final Paper
Islamic Intellectual Thought
Professor Fatima bint Abdullah
Abstract

This paper is an analysis of the available research and primary texts related to Ibn al Qayyim and an evaluation of his contribution to psychology. First the paper introduces the development of Islamic intellectual thought starting with revelation. Then there is a short description of the tradition of psychology and its historic significance. Then the contributions made by Ibn Al Qayyim are summarized and evaluated. In the end conclusions are made about how pervasive these contributions are to modern psychological practice and modern Islamic intellectual thought. 
Introduction
Islamic intellectual thought is a tradition grounded in the belief that Muhammad received revelations of the word of God through the Archangel Gabriel. Islam is one of the faiths that comprise the Abrahamic faith tradition along with Christianity and Judaism. Islamic intellectual thought begins with the revelations collated by Abu Bakr into the mushaf we know today. The mushaf is the collection of the words revealed to Muhamma through the Archangel Gabriel and organized into 30 volumes, 144 chapters and 6,236 verses. The words that make up this compilation establish the first conceptualization of Islamic thought. These verses were revealed over a span of 23 years starting with the first revelation when Muhammad was 40 years old in 609CE and ending in the year of his death 632CE. A portion of the verses are considered Makkiya and those are the verses that were revealed during the time that Muhammad spent in Makkah. The other portion of the verses are Madaniya and these verses were revealed to Muhammad in Madina. 
Without delving deep into the theological interwoven conflicts surrounding the collection of the verses and placement of those verses into respective positions we will discuss the aftermath of Muhammad’s death which will explain why there came to be a conflict regarding the leadership of Muslims and Islam. This will then explain why Islamic intellectual thought developed into a wide array of ideas and traditions, some of which are still dominant today; while others have faded over time. Directly after the death of Muhammad people were afraid that the religion would be wiped out. They had not expanded beyond Makkah and Madina and a few nearby locations. Some people were afraid that because Muhammad was gone that people would lose the faith that they once had. There were even instances of people claiming that they were the inheritors of Muhammad’s prophethood. This pushed Abu Bakr into the forefront who then took a stern position against anyone who was doubting the legitimacy of the faith and its continuity, even without the presence of Muhammad. Within three decades Islam spread as far east as China and west to Spain. 
Rightly Guided Khalifa
Khalifa, a largely misunderstood term. Khalifa comes from the root word “khalf” or coming after. Khalifa here means the successor. In the Islamic context this refers to the successor of Muhammad as the leader of the Muslim world. Abu Bakr’s role as the leader of the Muslims world brought forth the period known as the Khulafa al Rashidun or the Rightly Guided Caliphs. This was also a time of internal strife which led to a political split in the Muslim world with some of the companions of Muhammad taking the side of Muhammad’s relatives considering them the rightful heirs to his succession. Islamic religious traditions began to spread into new lands where different languages were spoken and different cultures were practiced. There was a need to develop a scientific method to pass on religious knowledge and authority. This expansion took Islam to north Africa, central Asia, east Asia, and into the heart of the Byzantine empire. Following Abu Bakr’s death Omar became the leader of the Muslim world. Under his reign Islam continued to spread to new lands including the capture of Jerusalem. Often times, western academic reviews of this period in Islamic history over looks the significance of Omar’s reign. Despite the fact that he was one of the most significant figures in Islamic history and played a significant role in legitimizing Muhammad’s prophethood among the Arab tribes in the Arabian peninsula and pushed fervently for the expansion of Islam to other lands. The reigns of Ali and Uthman are both equally significant and are a major focal point for the trajectory of Islam. Muslims who believed Muhammad’s direct relatives were the rightful successors to Muhammad’s prophethood were marginalized and at times engaged in direct conflict with other Muslims at times. By the time Muawiyah took Damascus by defeating Ali’s grandson Hassan the Islamic intellectual strains began to peel apart and take on a more identifiable form. 
Muslim Intellectual Thought Develops
During this time of conflict in the Muslim world it was also a time of ideological development and cultural exchange. The world was still lacking a global order and much of the inhabited world was still undiscovered by the traditional empirical powers such as the Byzantines or the Chinese. As Muawiyah ruled with an Amawi tradition of Islam he also managed to marginalize many scholars who organized themselves into a number of smaller traditions which we know today as Shia, Alawi, and Sufi Islam. These three strains of Islamic intellectual thought share a common quality and that is they are “mystical” in nature and form a “batini” or esoteric tradition in terms of textual interpretations and succession of spiritual knowledge and authority. These Islamic schools of thought were busy arranging, organizing and spreading Islamic ideas in all lands that they could reach. Then during the Abbasid caliphate, Harun Ibn Rashid, opened up Bayt ul Hikma or the House of Wisdom in Baghdad, Iraq. In this center for the exchange of knowledge scholars from all walks of life came to gain access to knowledge that was translated and transcribed from the native languages into Arabic and others. This effort brought into existence the traditions of Mutakallimun and Mutahadithoun. Extensive debates were had about the interpretation of specific words and texts and the practical application of religious laws specified in Quranic revelation or through the Hadith, the recorded traditions of Muhammad. The teachings of Aristotle and other greek philosophers were also translated and reinterpreted by Muslim scholars who developed their own applications for many of the Greek ideas. These in turn contributed to consecration of a variety of Islamic traditions which took on different political and spiritual roles. When the Mongols arrived from the east; records of a huge portion of these written works was washed away. Ironically, just like the Chinese printing press made the exchange of eastern and western traditions possible; the Mongols came from the east wiping out a significant portion of this tradition leaving us with an incomplete record of knowledge structures and intellectual thought inherited from these ancient times. Some historic records indicate that the River Tigris was colored black due to the ink that was washed away out of the pages of the books. Islamic intellectual thought continued to develop throughout the centuries with the center of Islamic power and influence moving to several different capitals in north Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. For the purposes of this paper we will turn to the conflexion of Islamic intellectual thought and knowledge structures related to the study of psychology.
History of the Study of Psychology
The tradition of psychology extends back to the ancient greek philosophers who first wrote about the nature of man, the mind, the spirit, and the soul. The writings of Aristotle, Plato, Socrates and others live on through their influence on modern ideas about the nature of man, freedom, justice, religion, and spirituality. One of the main issues that still forms the basis for much of the discourse within the tradition of psychology is the debate about the existence of free will and the debate about whether our natural existence determines our functions or whether the way we are nurtured has more of an influence. Documentation of this debate goes back to Plato who believed that human innate nature was predisposed to certain qualities while Aristotle believed that humans were born “tabula rasa” or blank slates which would be filled with life experience. Unfortunately, due to the dominance of ideas originating from mainly white males from five european countries the discussion of the traditions between the Greek philosophers and the Renaissance period is often ignored. The fact that Islamic intellectual traditions dominate the progression of intellectual thought between the Greek era and the renaissance makes them less referenced in the western academic tradition. We can see in the table presented in the report on the history of Psychology that between Aristotle and Thomas Hobbes no other thinkers, philosophers or historic figures were listed as offering significant contributions to psychology. 
This trend is prevalent in most western oriented circles of academia and is also a reason why this paper offers a new contribution to the pedagogical tradition of understanding the impact of Islamic intellectual thought on modern world views. 
Relationship between Modern Psychology and Muslim Psychological Traditions
Another important aspect of the psychological tradition is the nature of the issues that are dealt with and how they are dealt with. In ancient times the elaborate discussions about the nature of man, the existence of free will, the nature of the soul and the progression of man through the material life into metaphysical life are all issues of great concern. Even Muslims scholars developed elaborate schemas to explain why man thinks and behaves the way he does. Following the prophet’s death there were a number of Muslim scholars who wrote about issues found in the study of modern psychology but were written in philosophical texts. Many of the ideas developed by Muslims scholars were then dispersed over 1000 years into Europe and across the world directly influencing the ideas of modern intellectual thought and even study of psychology itself. Over time the way that such schemas are developed has become more scientific with the development of elaborate techniques to demonstrate specific psychological phenomena like brain activity imaging and controlled laboratory experiments. According to Benjamin and Baker technological advancements have made the science of psychology less subjective and more accurate in evaluating human behavior. Unfortunately, many of the theories and practices written by Muslim scholars on psychology are not translated to English and are thus not attributed to many modern day psychological practices and theories.
Ibn Qayyim Al Jawziyyah: Life and Work
“Repel the thought, for if you don’t, it becomes an idea. So repel the idea; for if you don’t it will become a desire. So fight against that (desire), for if you don’t, it will become a determination and a passion. And if you don’t repel that, it will become an action. And if you don’t replace it with its opposite, it will become a constant habit. So at that point, it will be difficult for you to change it.”
Ibn Qayyim al Jawziyyah was a 12th century Muslim scholar who came from an upper class family that was part of the religious authority of the Islamic caliphate at the time. Ibn Qayyim was the son of Abu Bakr who was the head of the Jawziyyah school in Damascus. Not surprisingly, Kraweitz, incorrectly places Ibn Qayyim’s origin to an a geographical region where his teacher was known to have come from. Taqi Udin Ahmad Ibn Taymiyyah, another notable Islamic scholar and teacher of Ibn Qayyim, was from Harran, an area in southeastern Turkey. In Krawietz’s introduction he makes the claim that Ibn Qayyim’s full name,  Abu ‘Abd Allah Shams al-Din Muhammad ibn Abu Bakr ibn Ayyub ibn Sa‘d ibn Harz ibn Makki Zayn al-Din al-Zur‘i al-Dimashqi al-Hanbali, indicates that his origin is from a geographical location known as Zur’i, which he equates with Daraa. Daraa is a city in southern Syria which is often referred to houran in Arabic. Phonetically it is similar to Harran but in fact they are two geographically different locations. This discrepancy is not surprising since the literature available in English on Muslim scholars is quite sparse. Resolving this discrepancy brings light to understanding better how Ibn Qayyim was so significantly influenced by Ibn Taymiyyah. Logically, it would make sense that Ibn Qayyim’s time in Damascus brought him to direct contact with Ibn Taymiyyah and his works since Ibn Taymiyyah fled to the Mamluk capital of Damascus in 1296 from Harran in southeastern Turkey while the Mongol’s pushed west. According to Kewaeitz’s explanation, he assumes Harran and Houran, being phonetically similar, enough so that he considers the two geographical regions to be quite near by to one another despite Damascus being directly in between the two regions and those two regions being several hundred kilometers apart. In fact, Ibn Qayyim remained imprisoned in the Citadel of Damascus due to one of Ibn Taymiyyah’s fatawa about visiting the graves of saints which landed he and his students in jail. Ibn Taymiyyah remained imprisoned until his death while Ibn Qayyim was released shortly after. 
Life and Work
Ibn Qayyim received extensive training in the traditional fields of Islamic scholarship including: Aqida (Islamic creed), Fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence), Tafsir (Quran exegesis), Ilm al Kalam (Islamic theology), and Arabic grammar. Ibn Qayyim wrote extensively on issues that were relevant to his time as well as issues relevant to the fundamental understandings of faith. He built on his teacher’s work on proving prophethood, Ighāthat al‐lahfān min maṣāʾid al‐Shayṭān (Rescuing the distressed from Satan's snares), by concluding that philosophers who thought prophet could not be proven because there was no physical evidence found in the physical existence of the prophet those philosophers were attributing prophethood to a specific class of people who in turn would represent the divine consecration of the public as a whole which in turn is to be understood as prophet. Growing up in the Mamluk state and having access to the most elite scholars of the time, Ibn Qayyim was given a thorough education in a number of fields becoming a prolific student of Ibn Taymiyyah and an expert Hanbali scholar. According to Abdul Azim Islahi, Ibn Qayyim also expanded on economic issues including “price control, market mechanism, supervision of economic activities (al-hisbah), riches and poverty, interest and zakah”. Compared to his teacher, Ibn Al Qayyim's writings were more concise and explanations were “easier to follow” with more than 100 of his published works in existence. Another powerful work of Ibn Qayyim was Ahkam ul Dhimmah, which is one of the most comprehensive medieval commentaries on Islamic perspectives on non Muslims living in Muslim administered lands. In this work Ibn Qayyim detailed positions on the role of non Muslims in a Muslim society including details about religious interactions, social interactions, financial interactions, and even details about their roles in the governance structures.  
Ibn Qayyim’s contributions to medieval Islamic and philosophical intellectual tradition is quite rich and comes to fruition in his work called Al Kafiyah al Shafiya. This book was directly impacted by the political and social circumstances of the time. The Mamluk dynasty in control of Damascus at the time was accustomed to venerating saints and dominated by the Mu'tazilah thinkers. Mu'tazilah were a group of Muslim scholars that dismissed some of the attributes of God and considered those who had committed major sins to neither be believers nor non believers; instead they were in a state of  manzila bayn al manzilatain, or a “a place between two places”. At the time, the threats that the Muslims leadership faced in Damascus were mainly from Christian crusaders and the Mongol’s. In order to deal with this threat the Caliph Nasir li din Allah decided to deal with the theological dissent of the time, which he attributed to the Muslim scholars influenced by the ancient greek philosophies. In the introduction to his commentary on Al Kafiyah al Shafiyah, Nitzman points out, in an attempt to prove Ibn Qayyim’s status as an elite scholar of his time, that Ibn Qayyim chose to use poetry to refute the ideas of the eloquent Mutazilah scholar Al Nazzam. Following in the tradition of his teacher Ibn Taymiyya, Ibn Al Qayyim continued to refute the ideas of the Mutazilah through his influence on his students. One of Ibn al Qayyim’s most notable students, Ibn Rajab, describes his teacher as ‘arif or ‘knower of god’. He goes on to describe Ibn Qayyim as a man devoted to night time prayers and contemplation on Quranic verses. This, Ibn Rajab emphasizes, was especially the case during Ibn Qayyim’s time imprisoned at the Citadel in Damascus; after which he was released and continued to produce works that Ibn Rajab believed made Ibn Qayyim a master of spiritual discourse or ‘ulum ‘ahlul ma’rifah’. Ibn Kathir, another notable student of Ibn Qayyim al Jawziyyah, also made contrasts between Ibn Qayyim’s approach to teaching and explaining with those of Ibn Taymiyyah.
Ibn Qayyim’s Contributions to Psychology 
Throughout history thinkers, philosophers and intellectuals have pondered on and written extensively about the nature of man’s existence. One contribution of Ibn Qayyim to the study of psychology is his categorization of pleasure. Understanding these categories of pleasures helps psychologists better understand how and why people are motivated to engage in certain activities. 
Ibn Qayyim’s Categories of Pleasure : 
Searching for things necessary for survival including food, shelter, and procreation
Advancing in social and professional circumstances to attain a position of power or authority
Living a life of virtue and dedication to God
These three categories of pleasure indicate that there is one very primal and innate category of pleasure and two others that are more related to a particular inclination. If a person is inclined to be more spiritual, then they will seek the third type of pleasure. Someone that is more interested in establishing himself as an authority figure will seek the second type of pleasure. Both types of people will need to seek the first type of pleasure because the need for sustenance such as food and genetic continuity are biological conditions that we cannot escape as humans. However, Ibn Qayyim indicates that there are different kinds of pleasure seeking: positive and negative. The way to tell the difference between the two is depending on the results. Ibn Qayyim states that any pleasure that results in pain is an illegitimate pleasure. Since seeking pleasure causes pain, thus making it unworthy; the only worthy pleasure is in the worship of God according to Ibn Qayyim. Ibn Qayyim went on to discuss the issue of satanic whispering or “waswasa” and explained that so long as the individual resisted these inclinations to negative pleasures then their “firasah”, or resilience, will grow stronger and eventually the person will get closer to God.
In another monument contribution to psychology Ibn Qayyim offers an explanation about how people think about things or contemplation. In his work, Miftah Dar as Saadah or the “Key to the House of Happiness”, Ibn Qayyim offers a description of the different types of thinking. Contemplation is done in a number of ways and understood to be a multi level operation that has developed into a field of study founded by Dr B Alan Wallace. He coined the term “contemplative science” which is defined as “the bridge between the empirical study of the science of consciousness and the subjective, experiential study of consciousness through contemplation”. Centuries before this concept was developed; Ibn Qayyim explained in his own way the process of thinking. Now known as metacognition, is the study of how people think.  For his part, Ibn Qayyim identified four different types of thinking described below. The first two types of thinking are ways that thoughts come in to the conscious awareness of a person’s cognitive space. The next two types of thinking are responsible for taking these thoughts to a more advanced level of understanding and insight. 
Ibn Qayyim’s types of thinking : 
Tafakkur - the active process of bringing thought resulting from environmental or innate inspiration into the conscious cognitive space
Tadhakur - a concept stemming from the Quranic verse that describes a person who remembers some knowledge they have previously attained after being distracted 
I’tibar - a thinking process that takes a thought into a new form and results in the creation of a new thought that is more advanced than previous thoughts
Tadabur - when a person considers the verses of the Quran and contemplates their meaning in their own life
The relationship between Ibn Qayyim’s types of thinking is quite intricate and work symbiotically allowing the human conscience to remain active, gain insight, recall past knowledge, and gain insight into the previously attained knowledge through the processing of new experiences. In Ibn Qayyim’s Miftah Dar Saadah he explains that tafakur gives the heart something it did not have and tadhakur allows the heart to preserve that knowledge in retrievable format. Tadabur, the most profound form of thinking, is an amalgamation of all the types of thinking, resulting in a superior state of consciousness in which a person is fully aware of the existence of specific knowledge placing their state of thought completely at the dispense of God. Such that, a person who engages in tadabur will accept that all that befalls them is from God and the wisdom resulting from these occurrences are from God. This state of thought will allow a believer to move through life having a positive understanding of the situation around them and keep them committed to positive thinking and searching out good forms of pleasure that will bring them closer to God.  
Ibn Qayyim spends much time considering the matter of thoughts in order to understand human behavior. This is very similar to what modern psychologists do in a majority of their work. For Ibn Qayyim, understanding the way people think was the beginning of  a series of events that took place which result in behavior and ultimately the worldly manifestation of belief of disbelief. For Ibn Qayyim knowledge should be beneficial if it were going to be considered knowledge. He theorized that a the first step in behavior was “fikr”, or “thought”. Fikr is the arabic word for thought which is also the root word for “tafakur”. If a thought was beneficial and benefited a person spiritually then that thought could develop into “ilm” or knowledge. If the thought was not positive the it would revert back into the state of “fikr”. Based on our thoughts and knowledge we apply them according to a value system. If that value system prefers truth then the resulting knowledge structures, or “haal”, are also truthful in that the individual “ilm” elements that combine to form the “haal” or knowledge structure, are all truthful as well. Interestingly, based on Ibn Qayyim’s theory it is understood that he dismisses knowledge structures that are not built to attain an advantage or positive growth in terms of spirituality and closeness to God.  Ibn Qayyim explains how a higher level of spiritual existence can be attained through his theory of “Three Orders of Meaning”. Through these orders of meanings a person is able to process information and turn them into actions. However, along the way any distractions or sins that might “blind” them from knowledge will prevent them from reaching a state of “haal”. The orders of thinking correspond with the stages of thought described above. For those who are unable to attain spiritual enlightenment they will neither be able to accept the truth or deny falsehood. However, for those who attain a “haal” that is beneficial to them in their spiritual journey they will develop an “iradah” or innate motivation (ambitions, wills, choices, and decisions) that will result in a positive behavior. 
Conclusion
Ibn Qayyim has many other works and concepts that take into consideration human behavior, thinking, and emotional condition. The ideas presented in this paper are mean to give the reader a basic introduction to the concepts developed by Ibn Qayyim and specific examples of his contribution to the study of what we know today as ‘psychology’. It is clear from Ibn Qayyim’s ideas that his main motivation was attaining a higher spiritual standing and feeding his desire to please God. His works are filled with discussions about the purification of the soul, the different states on unconsciousness, and explanations of why people behave the way they do. Unfortunately, there are not detailed translations of his original works available for researchers to access. Increased efforts to translate and collate Ibn Qayyim’s specific contributions to modern psychology will provide a significant contribution to the understanding of human thought and behavior as well as the contribution of classic Islamic intellectual thought to modern fields of scientific enquiry.

Khalifa, a largely misunderstood term. Khalifa comes from the root word “khalf” or coming after. Khalifa here means the successor. In the Islamic context this refers to the successor of Muhammad as the leader of the Muslim world. Abu Bakr’s role as the leader of the Muslims world brought forth the period known as the Khulafa al Rashidun or the Rightly Guided Caliphs. This was also a time of internal strife which led to a political split in the Muslim world with some of the companions of Muhammad taking the side of Muhammad’s relatives considering them the rightful heirs to his succession. Islamic religious traditions began to spread into new lands where different languages were spoken and different cultures were practiced. There was a need to develop a scientific method to pass on religious knowledge and authority. This expansion took Islam to north Africa, central Asia, east Asia, and into the heart of the Byzantine empire. Following Abu Bakr’s death Omar became the leader of the Muslim world. Under his reign Islam continued to spread to new lands including the capture of Jerusalem. Often times, western academic reviews of this period in Islamic history over looks the significance of Omar’s reign. Despite the fact that he was one of the most significant figures in Islamic history and played a significant role in legitimizing Muhammad’s prophethood among the Arab tribes in the Arabian peninsula and pushed fervently for the expansion of Islam to other lands. The reigns of Ali and Uthman are both equally significant and are a major focal point for the trajectory of Islam. Muslims who believed Muhammad’s direct relatives were the rightful successors to Muhammad’s prophethood were marginalized and at times engaged in direct conflict with other Muslims at times. By the time Muawiyah took Damascus by defeating Ali’s grandson Hassan the Islamic intellectual strains began to peel apart and take on a more identifiable form. 
Muslim Intellectual Thought Develops
During this time of conflict in the Muslim world it was also a time of ideological development and cultural exchange. The world was still lacking a global order and much of the inhabited world was still undiscovered by the traditional empirical powers such as the Byzantines or the Chinese. As Muawiyah ruled with an Amawi tradition of Islam he also managed to marginalize many scholars who organized themselves into a number of smaller traditions which we know today as Shia, Alawi, and Sufi Islam. These three strains of Islamic intellectual thought share a common quality and that is they are “mystical” in nature and form a “batini” or esoteric tradition in terms of textual interpretations and succession of spiritual knowledge and authority. These Islamic schools of thought were busy arranging, organizing and spreading Islamic ideas in all lands that they could reach. Then during the Abbasid caliphate, Harun Ibn Rashid, opened up Bayt ul Hikma or the House of Wisdom in Baghdad, Iraq. In this center for the exchange of knowledge scholars from all walks of life came to gain access to knowledge that was translated and transcribed from the native languages into Arabic and others. This effort brought into existence the traditions of Mutakallimun and Mutahadithoun. Extensive debates were had about the interpretation of specific words and texts and the practical application of religious laws specified in Quranic revelation or through the Hadith, the recorded traditions of Muhammad. The teachings of Aristotle and other greek philosophers were also translated and reinterpreted by Muslim scholars who developed their own applications for many of the Greek ideas. These in turn contributed to consecration of a variety of Islamic traditions which took on different political and spiritual roles. When the Mongols arrived from the east; records of a huge portion of these written works was washed away. Ironically, just like the Chinese printing press made the exchange of eastern and western traditions possible; the Mongols came from the east wiping out a significant portion of this tradition leaving us with an incomplete record of knowledge structures and intellectual thought inherited from these ancient times. Some historic records indicate that the River Tigris was colored black due to the ink that was washed away out of the pages of the books. Islamic intellectual thought continued to develop throughout the centuries with the center of Islamic power and influence moving to several different capitals in north Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. For the purposes of this paper we will turn to the conflexion of Islamic intellectual thought and knowledge structures related to the study of psychology.
History of the Study of Psychology
The tradition of psychology extends back to the ancient greek philosophers who first wrote about the nature of man, the mind, the spirit, and the soul. The writings of Aristotle, Plato, Socrates and others live on through their influence on modern ideas about the nature of man, freedom, justice, religion, and spirituality. One of the main issues that still forms the basis for much of the discourse within the tradition of psychology is the debate about the existence of free will and the debate about whether our natural existence determines our functions or whether the way we are nurtured has more of an influence. Documentation of this debate goes back to Plato who believed that human innate nature was predisposed to certain qualities while Aristotle believed that humans were born “tabula rasa” or blank slates which would be filled with life experience. Unfortunately, due to the dominance of ideas originating from mainly white males from five european countries the discussion of the traditions between the Greek philosophers and the Renaissance period is often ignored. The fact that Islamic intellectual traditions dominate the progression of intellectual thought between the Greek era and the renaissance makes them less referenced in the western academic tradition. We can see in the table presented in the report on the history of Psychology that between Aristotle and Thomas Hobbes no other thinkers, philosophers or historic figures were listed as offering significant contributions to psychology. 
This trend is prevalent in most western oriented circles of academia and is also a reason why this paper offers a new contribution to the pedagogical tradition of understanding the impact of Islamic intellectual thought on modern world views. 
Relationship between Modern Psychology and Muslim Psychological Traditions
Another important aspect of the psychological tradition is the nature of the issues that are dealt with and how they are dealt with. In ancient times the elaborate discussions about the nature of man, the existence of free will, the nature of the soul and the progression of man through the material life into metaphysical life are all issues of great concern. Even Muslims scholars developed elaborate schemas to explain why man thinks and behaves the way he does. Following the prophet’s death there were a number of Muslim scholars who wrote about issues found in the study of modern psychology but were written in philosophical texts. Many of the ideas developed by Muslims scholars were then dispersed over 1000 years into Europe and across the world directly influencing the ideas of modern intellectual thought and even study of psychology itself. Over time the way that such schemas are developed has become more scientific with the development of elaborate techniques to demonstrate specific psychological phenomena like brain activity imaging and controlled laboratory experiments. According to Benjamin and Baker technological advancements have made the science of psychology less subjective and more accurate in evaluating human behavior. Unfortunately, many of the theories and practices written by Muslim scholars on psychology are not translated to English and are thus not attributed to many modern day psychological practices and theories.
Ibn Qayyim Al Jawziyyah: Life and Work
“Repel the thought, for if you don’t, it becomes an idea. So repel the idea; for if you don’t it will become a desire. So fight against that (desire), for if you don’t, it will become a determination and a passion. And if you don’t repel that, it will become an action. And if you don’t replace it with its opposite, it will become a constant habit. So at that point, it will be difficult for you to change it.”
Ibn Qayyim al Jawziyyah was a 12th century Muslim scholar who came from an upper class family that was part of the religious authority of the Islamic caliphate at the time. Ibn Qayyim was the son of Abu Bakr who was the head of the Jawziyyah school in Damascus. Not surprisingly, Kraweitz, incorrectly places Ibn Qayyim’s origin to an a geographical region where his teacher was known to have come from. Taqi Udin Ahmad Ibn Taymiyyah, another notable Islamic scholar and teacher of Ibn Qayyim, was from Harran, an area in southeastern Turkey. In Krawietz’s introduction he makes the claim that Ibn Qayyim’s full name,  Abu ‘Abd Allah Shams al-Din Muhammad ibn Abu Bakr ibn Ayyub ibn Sa‘d ibn Harz ibn Makki Zayn al-Din al-Zur‘i al-Dimashqi al-Hanbali, indicates that his origin is from a geographical location known as Zur’i, which he equates with Daraa. Daraa is a city in southern Syria which is often referred to houran in Arabic. Phonetically it is similar to Harran but in fact they are two geographically different locations. This discrepancy is not surprising since the literature available in English on Muslim scholars is quite sparse. Resolving this discrepancy brings light to understanding better how Ibn Qayyim was so significantly influenced by Ibn Taymiyyah. Logically, it would make sense that Ibn Qayyim’s time in Damascus brought him to direct contact with Ibn Taymiyyah and his works since Ibn Taymiyyah fled to the Mamluk capital of Damascus in 1296 from Harran in southeastern Turkey while the Mongol’s pushed west. According to Kewaeitz’s explanation, he assumes Harran and Houran, being phonetically similar, enough so that he considers the two geographical regions to be quite near by to one another despite Damascus being directly in between the two regions and those two regions being several hundred kilometers apart. In fact, Ibn Qayyim remained imprisoned in the Citadel of Damascus due to one of Ibn Taymiyyah’s fatawa about visiting the graves of saints which landed he and his students in jail. Ibn Taymiyyah remained imprisoned until his death while Ibn Qayyim was released shortly after. 
Life and Work
Ibn Qayyim received extensive training in the traditional fields of Islamic scholarship including: Aqida (Islamic creed), Fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence), Tafsir (Quran exegesis), Ilm al Kalam (Islamic theology), and Arabic grammar. Ibn Qayyim wrote extensively on issues that were relevant to his time as well as issues relevant to the fundamental understandings of faith. He built on his teacher’s work on proving prophethood, Ighāthat al‐lahfān min maṣāʾid al‐Shayṭān (Rescuing the distressed from Satan's snares), by concluding that philosophers who thought prophet could not be proven because there was no physical evidence found in the physical existence of the prophet those philosophers were attributing prophethood to a specific class of people who in turn would represent the divine consecration of the public as a whole which in turn is to be understood as prophet. Growing up in the Mamluk state and having access to the most elite scholars of the time, Ibn Qayyim was given a thorough education in a number of fields becoming a prolific student of Ibn Taymiyyah and an expert Hanbali scholar. According to Abdul Azim Islahi, Ibn Qayyim also expanded on economic issues including “price control, market mechanism, supervision of economic activities (al-hisbah), riches and poverty, interest and zakah”. Compared to his teacher, Ibn Al Qayyim's writings were more concise and explanations were “easier to follow” with more than 100 of his published works in existence. Another powerful work of Ibn Qayyim was Ahkam ul Dhimmah, which is one of the most comprehensive medieval commentaries on Islamic perspectives on non Muslims living in Muslim administered lands. In this work Ibn Qayyim detailed positions on the role of non Muslims in a Muslim society including details about religious interactions, social interactions, financial interactions, and even details about their roles in the governance structures.  
Ibn Qayyim’s contributions to medieval Islamic and philosophical intellectual tradition is quite rich and comes to fruition in his work called Al Kafiyah al Shafiya. This book was directly impacted by the political and social circumstances of the time. The Mamluk dynasty in control of Damascus at the time was accustomed to venerating saints and dominated by the Mu'tazilah thinkers. Mu'tazilah were a group of Muslim scholars that dismissed some of the attributes of God and considered those who had committed major sins to neither be believers nor non believers; instead they were in a state of  manzila bayn al manzilatain, or a “a place between two places”. At the time, the threats that the Muslims leadership faced in Damascus were mainly from Christian crusaders and the Mongol’s. In order to deal with this threat the Caliph Nasir li din Allah decided to deal with the theological dissent of the time, which he attributed to the Muslim scholars influenced by the ancient greek philosophies. In the introduction to his commentary on Al Kafiyah al Shafiyah, Nitzman points out, in an attempt to prove Ibn Qayyim’s status as an elite scholar of his time, that Ibn Qayyim chose to use poetry to refute the ideas of the eloquent Mutazilah scholar Al Nazzam. Following in the tradition of his teacher Ibn Taymiyya, Ibn Al Qayyim continued to refute the ideas of the Mutazilah through his influence on his students. One of Ibn al Qayyim’s most notable students, Ibn Rajab, describes his teacher as ‘arif or ‘knower of god’. He goes on to describe Ibn Qayyim as a man devoted to night time prayers and contemplation on Quranic verses. This, Ibn Rajab emphasizes, was especially the case during Ibn Qayyim’s time imprisoned at the Citadel in Damascus; after which he was released and continued to produce works that Ibn Rajab believed made Ibn Qayyim a master of spiritual discourse or ‘ulum ‘ahlul ma’rifah’. Ibn Kathir, another notable student of Ibn Qayyim al Jawziyyah, also made contrasts between Ibn Qayyim’s approach to teaching and explaining with those of Ibn Taymiyyah.
Ibn Qayyim’s Contributions to Psychology 
Throughout history thinkers, philosophers and intellectuals have pondered on and written extensively about the nature of man’s existence. One contribution of Ibn Qayyim to the study of psychology is his categorization of pleasure. Understanding these categories of pleasures helps psychologists better understand how and why people are motivated to engage in certain activities. 
Ibn Qayyim’s Categories of Pleasure : 
Searching for things necessary for survival including food, shelter, and procreation
Advancing in social and professional circumstances to attain a position of power or authority
Living a life of virtue and dedication to God
These three categories of pleasure indicate that there is one very primal and innate category of pleasure and two others that are more related to a particular inclination. If a person is inclined to be more spiritual, then they will seek the third type of pleasure. Someone that is more interested in establishing himself as an authority figure will seek the second type of pleasure. Both types of people will need to seek the first type of pleasure because the need for sustenance such as food and genetic continuity are biological conditions that we cannot escape as humans. However, Ibn Qayyim indicates that there are different kinds of pleasure seeking: positive and negative. The way to tell the difference between the two is depending on the results. Ibn Qayyim states that any pleasure that results in pain is an illegitimate pleasure. Since seeking pleasure causes pain, thus making it unworthy; the only worthy pleasure is in the worship of God according to Ibn Qayyim. Ibn Qayyim went on to discuss the issue of satanic whispering or “waswasa” and explained that so long as the individual resisted these inclinations to negative pleasures then their “firasah”, or resilience, will grow stronger and eventually the person will get closer to God.
In another monument contribution to psychology Ibn Qayyim offers an explanation about how people think about things or contemplation. In his work, Miftah Dar as Saadah or the “Key to the House of Happiness”, Ibn Qayyim offers a description of the different types of thinking. Contemplation is done in a number of ways and understood to be a multi level operation that has developed into a field of study founded by Dr B Alan Wallace. He coined the term “contemplative science” which is defined as “the bridge between the empirical study of the science of consciousness and the subjective, experiential study of consciousness through contemplation”. Centuries before this concept was developed; Ibn Qayyim explained in his own way the process of thinking. Now known as metacognition, is the study of how people think.  For his part, Ibn Qayyim identified four different types of thinking described below. The first two types of thinking are ways that thoughts come in to the conscious awareness of a person’s cognitive space. The next two types of thinking are responsible for taking these thoughts to a more advanced level of understanding and insight. 
Ibn Qayyim’s types of thinking : 
Tafakkur - the active process of bringing thought resulting from environmental or innate inspiration into the conscious cognitive space
Tadhakur - a concept stemming from the Quranic verse that describes a person who remembers some knowledge they have previously attained after being distracted 
I’tibar - a thinking process that takes a thought into a new form and results in the creation of a new thought that is more advanced than previous thoughts
Tadabur - when a person considers the verses of the Quran and contemplates their meaning in their own life
The relationship between Ibn Qayyim’s types of thinking is quite intricate and work symbiotically allowing the human conscience to remain active, gain insight, recall past knowledge, and gain insight into the previously attained knowledge through the processing of new experiences. In Ibn Qayyim’s Miftah Dar Saadah he explains that tafakur gives the heart something it did not have and tadhakur allows the heart to preserve that knowledge in retrievable format. Tadabur, the most profound form of thinking, is an amalgamation of all the types of thinking, resulting in a superior state of consciousness in which a person is fully aware of the existence of specific knowledge placing their state of thought completely at the dispense of God. Such that, a person who engages in tadabur will accept that all that befalls them is from God and the wisdom resulting from these occurrences are from God. This state of thought will allow a believer to move through life having a positive understanding of the situation around them and keep them committed to positive thinking and searching out good forms of pleasure that will bring them closer to God.  
Ibn Qayyim spends much time considering the matter of thoughts in order to understand human behavior. This is very similar to what modern psychologists do in a majority of their work. For Ibn Qayyim, understanding the way people think was the beginning of  a series of events that took place which result in behavior and ultimately the worldly manifestation of belief of disbelief. For Ibn Qayyim knowledge should be beneficial if it were going to be considered knowledge. He theorized that a the first step in behavior was “fikr”, or “thought”. Fikr is the arabic word for thought which is also the root word for “tafakur”. If a thought was beneficial and benefited a person spiritually then that thought could develop into “ilm” or knowledge. If the thought was not positive the it would revert back into the state of “fikr”. Based on our thoughts and knowledge we apply them according to a value system. If that value system prefers truth then the resulting knowledge structures, or “haal”, are also truthful in that the individual “ilm” elements that combine to form the “haal” or knowledge structure, are all truthful as well. Interestingly, based on Ibn Qayyim’s theory it is understood that he dismisses knowledge structures that are not built to attain an advantage or positive growth in terms of spirituality and closeness to God.  Ibn Qayyim explains how a higher level of spiritual existence can be attained through his theory of “Three Orders of Meaning”. Through these orders of meanings a person is able to process information and turn them into actions. However, along the way any distractions or sins that might “blind” them from knowledge will prevent them from reaching a state of “haal”. The orders of thinking correspond with the stages of thought described above. For those who are unable to attain spiritual enlightenment they will neither be able to accept the truth or deny falsehood. However, for those who attain a “haal” that is beneficial to them in their spiritual journey they will develop an “iradah” or innate motivation (ambitions, wills, choices, and decisions) that will result in a positive behavior. 
Conclusion
Ibn Qayyim has many other works and concepts that take into consideration human behavior, thinking, and emotional condition. The ideas presented in this paper are mean to give the reader a basic introduction to the concepts developed by Ibn Qayyim and specific examples of his contribution to the study of what we know today as ‘psychology’. It is clear from Ibn Qayyim’s ideas that his main motivation was attaining a higher spiritual standing and feeding his desire to please God. His works are filled with discussions about the purification of the soul, the different states on unconsciousness, and explanations of why people behave the way they do. Unfortunately, there are not detailed translations of his original works available for researchers to access. Increased efforts to translate and collate Ibn Qayyim’s specific contributions to modern psychology will provide a significant contribution to the understanding of human thought and behavior as well as the contribution of classic Islamic intellectual thought to modern fields of scientific enquiry.

Alright, I've read through your paper on Ibn Qayyim. Rather than just summarize it back to you, let me ask you some questions that'll help us both figure out what you're actually grasping here:

**1. The Architecture Question:**
Ibn Qayyim presents this sequence: thought (fikr) → knowledge (ilm) → knowledge structure (haal) → motivation (iradah) → behavior. But he also presents four types of thinking (tafakkur, tadhakur, i'tibar, tadabur). How do these two frameworks relate to each other? Are they describing the same process at different resolutions, or are they parallel systems?

**2. The Tension Question:**
The paper claims Ibn Qayyim says "any pleasure that results in pain is an illegitimate pleasure" and therefore "the only worthy pleasure is in the worship of God." But his first category of pleasure is survival needs - food, shelter, procreation. These definitely can result in pain. Is this a contradiction, or is there something more nuanced going on that the paper isn't capturing?

**3. The Application Question:**
You're building personality assessments based on medieval Islamic psychological frameworks. Which of Ibn Qayyim's contributions here would actually be *measurable* or *observable* in a way that could inform an assessment? And which are more philosophical/theological constructs that might resist that kind of operationalization?

**4. The Missing Piece Question:**
The paper repeatedly mentions that Ibn Qayyim's works aren't well translated and that Islamic contributions between Greek philosophy and the Renaissance are ignored. But - does this paper actually demonstrate that Ibn Qayyim's ideas influenced modern psychology, or just that they're parallel? What's the difference, and why does it matter?

Start with whichever question pulls at you. I'm curious where your understanding is solid and where it's more like "I read these words but I'm not sure I've really *got* it yet."
